questions.text: A 45-year-old male came to the casualty with a history of hyperlipidemia, diabetes and hypertension. The right eye is down and out with paralysis of the left leg. You ordered an MRI which is shown below.what is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medial midbrain syndrome. The patient with down and out eye, paralysis of the left leg with risk factors for stroke (Hyperlipidemia, hypertension) and on t1 weighted MRI shows hyperintensity in the region of the medial midbrain suggests Ischemic stroke.

Highyeild:

Medial midbrain syndrome (paramedian branches of upper basilar and proximal posterior cerebral arteries)- On the side of the lesion: Eye “down and out” -secondary to unopposed action of fourth and sixth cranial nerves, with dilated and unresponsive pupil (Third nerve fibres affected). On the side opposite lesion: Paralysis of face, arm, and leg : Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract descending in crus cerebri. Lateral midbrain syndrome (syndrome of small penetrating arteries arising from a posterior cerebral artery) - On the side of the lesion: Eye “down and out”- secondary to unopposed action of fourth and sixth cranial nerves, with dilated and unresponsive pupil ( Third nerve fibres and/or third nerve nucleus affected) On the side opposite lesion: Hemiataxia, hyperkinesia, tremor : Red nucleus , dentatorubrothalamic pathway.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Lateral midbrain syndrome-patient will have Hemiataxia, Hyperkinesia. Option: C.Lateral medullary syndrome -patient will have C/L loss of pain and temperature, I/L ataxia, I/L Horner’s syndrome, I/L loss of face sensation, Dysphagia, Dysarthria and I/L loss of taste.

Extraedge:

Management of acute stroke. For suspected strokes identified by prehospital professionals, we encourage calling ahead to the destination hospital. This allows early "stroke code" activation to prepare for an emergent computed tomography (CT) on arrival. For patients with onset <6 h from the last time seen normal, we expedite a non-contrast head CT scan, and if free of haemorrhage and the patient is IV plasminogen activator (PA) eligible, this is administered in the CT scanner. (For IV tissue PA [tPA], the bolus is given and infusion initiated; for tenecteplase, the full dose is given as a bolus). Then CT angiography (CTA) from the left atrium to the skull vertex is performed to identify an eligible target lesion for thrombectomy. For a patient presenting in the 6- to 24-h time window, PA is not considered, and the decision to perform thrombectomy is based on perfusion imaging.

questions.text: 58 yrs old male with h/o hypertension & diabetes for 20 yrs, presents with sudden onset of right arm & leg weakness along with speech difficulty. He is accompanied by his wife to the ER approximately 30 mins before the onset of symptoms. The resident asked for a blood glucose evaluation and a CT head. CT is suggestive of ischemic stroke and edema less than1/3rd of MCA. 1hr had passed and the stroke team had decided to go for Thrombolytic therapy with Alteplase. All of the following are true about the thrombolytic therapy and this patient, except?

options.label: A
options.text: BP should be less than 185/110mmHg before starting Thrombolytic therapy.

options.label: B
options.text: Thrombolysis is indicated in hemorrhagic shock with edema more than 1/3rd of MCA.

options.label: C
options.text: Antiplatelet to be started only 24hrs after Thrombolytic therapy.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid Foley’s catheter immediately after Thrombolytic therapy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Thrombolysis is indicated in hemorrhagic shock with edema more than 1/3rd of MCA.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thrombolysis is indicated in hemorrhagic shock with edema more than 1/3rd of MCA.

Highyeild:

Administration of Intravenous Recombinant Tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA) for Acute Ischemic Stroke (AIS) a INDICATION CONTRAINDICATION Clinical diagnosis of stroke The onset of symptoms to time of drug administration ≤4.5 h b CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3 of the MCA territory Age ≥18 years Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment Bleeding diathesis Recent head injury or intracerebral haemorrhage Major surgery in the preceding 14 days Gastrointestinal bleeding in the preceding 21 days Recent myocardial infarction Administration of rtPA IV access with two peripheral IV lines (avoid arterial or central line placement) Review eligibility for rtPA Administer 0.9 mg/kg IV (maximum 90 mg) IV as 10% of the total dose by bolus, followed by the remainder of the total dose over 1 h c Frequent cuff BP monitoring No other antithrombotic treatment for 24 h For the decline in neurologic status or uncontrolled BP, stop an infusion, give cryoprecipitate, and reimage the brain emergently Avoid urethral catheterization for ≥2 h "See Activase (tissue plasminogen activator) package insert for a complete list of contraindications and dosing. 'Depending on the country, IV rtPA may be approved for up to 4.5 h with additional restrictions. A dose of 0.6 mg/kg is commonly used in Asia (Japan and China) based on randomized data indicating less haemorrhage and similar efficacy using this lower dose. Abbreviations: BP, blood pressure; CT, computed tomography; MCA, middle cerebral artery.

Random:

Explanation For Other Options:- Option A, C, & D are correct statements. Option: A. BP should be less than 185/110mmHg before starting Thrombolytic therapy as BP> 185/110 is a contraindication to administration of Intravenous Recombinant Tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA) . Option: C. Antiplatelets to be started only 24hrs after Thrombolytic therapy -the early application of anti-platelet-aggregation drugs caused increased risk of cerebral hemorrhage . The current clinical guidelines do not recommend the use of anti-platelet drugs within 24 h after thrombolysis. Option: D. Avoid Foley’s catheter immediately after Thrombolytic therapy -Foley catheterisation should be avoided for ≥2 hr to prevent bleeding .

questions.text: A 69-year-old diabetic presents with right-sided weakness. The weakness is equal in the right face, arm, and leg. Sensation, speech, and comprehension are intact. Select the site of the lesion.

options.label: D
options.text: Penetrating branch of middle cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: D. Penetrating branch of middle cerebral artery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Penetrating branch of middle cerebral artery Penetrating branch of the middle cerebral artery occlusion is presented with the syndrome of pure motor hemiplegia. The infarct involves only the posterior limb of the Internal capsule, impairing motor fibres to the face, arm, and leg. Occlusion of a penetrating artery causes a lacunar infarct.

Highyeild:

Middle cerebral artery occlusion- Inferior division of MCA occlusion- Dominant hemisphere→Wernicke’s Aphasia No weakness/ hemianesthesia Homonymous superior Quadrantanopia Dominant hemisphere-Gerstmann syndrome Non-dominant hemisphere-Spatial agnosia, hemineglect. Superior division of MCA occlusion- Broca’s aphasia C/L hemiplegia-dominant MCA lesion]C/L weakness-Hand and arm> Leg: Brachial syndrome Face weakness Sensory loss: Hand and arm >Leg Homonymous inferior quadrantanopia.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Posterior cerebral artery -It presents with bilateral homonymous hemianopia, cortical blindness, awareness or denial of blindness. Failure to see to-and-fro movements, inability to perceive objects not centrally located, apraxia of ocular movements, inability to count or enumerate objects. Option: B. Middle cerebral artery -Occlusion of the entire middle cerebral artery results in contralateral hemiplegia, hemianesthesia , and homonymous hemianopia with or without global aphasia. Option: C. Anterior cerebral artery -It presents with profound abulia (a delay in verbal and motor response ) and bilateral pyramidal signs with paraparesis or quadriparesis and urinary incontinence result.
